webTitle: House prices expected to continue to rise as boom fails to attract sellers

fields.standfirst: April was the fourth consecutive month to experience a fall in properties coming on to the market, according to RICS survey
fields.body:
House prices are expected to continue rising through the summer after sector figures showed Britain's year-long property boom has failed to attract enough sellers to meet demand.

April was the fourth consecutive month to experience a fall in properties coming on to the market, according to a survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics). But buyer inquiries are starting to fall in London amid "tentative signs" that the market in the capital is cooling.

Rising UK prices remain the overarching trend outlined by the professional body for surveyors and estate agents. Without a steep increase in the number of sellers willing to put their homes up for sale prices are likely to maintain the rapid rise that began last spring. The most recent house price survey by Nationwide showed prices rising by almost 11% across the UK and 18% in London.

The Rics report comes a day after warnings from the Organisation for Economic co-operation and Development that the rampant housing market threatens to destabilise the UK economy and that the government should consider further measures to restrain price inflation.

The respected international thinktank said UK regulators should consider imposing tougher borrowing rules on buyers, and possibly restrict the Help to Buy mortgage subsidy scheme.

A deputy governor at the Bank of England, Sir Jon Cunliffe, said last week that it would be dangerous to ignore the momentum building up in the housing market.

Simon Rubinsohn, chief economist at Rics, said: "Everyone hoped for a spring bounce in the number of homes being put on the market, but it hasn't happened. If you look at five of the last seven months, we have seen a negative reading from our survey, which means more of our members are seeing falls in the number of new instructions than there are members who see an increase."

Rubinsohn said that despite the downward trend in instructions, the average number of homes sold per chartered surveyor hit its highest level since February 2008. The Rics residential market survey for April found that 26% more chartered surveyors reported an increase in the number of agreed sales.

The report showed that nine UK regions reported declines in new property coming on to the market. In the north-west, 62% more chartered surveyors predict prices over the next three months will rise, rather than fall. In East Anglia the figure is 57%. By comparison in London, 49% more respondents reported similar expectations, down from 61% in March.

Rubinsohn said all regions were buoyant and seeing price rises, though the strength of the London market was starting to wane.

"It's interesting that buyer inquiries are starting to fall in the capital. I wouldn't overplay this. The London market is still very strong and they are just tentative signs at the moment, but it is something we are starting to see," he said. "It's not clear yet whether buyers are suffering from affordability constraints after a period of strong price rises, hitting tougher lending rules or just looking around and seeing less property available and delaying their buying decisions."

Richard Batley, a senior analyst at economic consultancy Lombard Street Research, said it was possible the dearth of homes coming onto the market was due to older homeowners planning to downsize and hanging on for higher values.

"It was obvious from Cunliffe's remarks that most people are moving because they are coping with life changing events. Those who are thinking of selling to maximise value can see the market rising and are biding their time," he said.

Much of the debate around increasing the supply of homes has focused on newly built properties. The supply of new homes has increased dramatically in the last year, but still remains on a relatively small scale in relation to demand.

Rubinsohn, said: "The critical issue for the market remains the lack of second hand supply with our numbers suggesting that the picture is, if anything, getting worse.

"It is too early to conclude whether this will undermine the positive trend in transactions volumes, but clearly the absence of properties to buy will ultimately be a factor in influencing the ability of people to move home."

webTitle: Lloyd's calls on insurers to take into account climate-change risk

fields.standfirst: Extreme weather as global climate alters demands a longer view and more action to avoid financial losses, says insurance firm
fields.body:
Lloyd's of London, the world's oldest and biggest insurance market, has for the first time called on insurers to incorporate climate change into their models.

The call to action comes a day after a landmark US report, named the National Climate Assessment, which has warned that climate change is wreaking havoc across the US.

Lloyd's says damage and weather-related losses around the world have increased from an annual average of $50bn in the 1980s to close to $200bn over the last 10 years.

The 326-year-old insurance market, whose members write insurance business worldwide, believes the time has come for a formal call on the industry to take into account various climate-change scenarios to avoid unpredictable losses to businesses.

What the industry describes as extreme weather events have increased in number and severity as the global climate system has altered, causing more and bigger hurricanes, typhoons and heatwaves around the world. In the UK the main climate-change related risk is flooding.

Typhoon Haiyan, which last November swept across south-east Asia, especially affecting the Philippines, was one of the strongest tropical cyclones ever recorded.

The year 2011 was the most expensive on record for natural disasters, with insured losses costing the industry more than $126bn.

Superstorm Sandy caused $35bn of insured losses two years ago, making it the second costliest hurricane in US history after hurricane Katrina in 2005.

A new report by Lloyd's, which consulted the world's largest catastrophe modelling firms, says a 20cm rise in the sea level at the southern tip of Manhattan Island increased Superstorm Sandy's surge losses by 30% (up to $8bn) in New York alone.

The 840-page National Climate Assessment, published this week, was described by John Holdren, the White House science adviser, as the "loudest and clearest alarm bell to date signalling the need to take urgent action to combat the threats to Americans from climate change".

Trevor Maynard, head of exposure management and reinsurance at Lloyd's, said: "Climate change is very much here to stay. Hurricanes are getting stronger worldwide, and especially over the north Atlantic … At the moment we are heading for a rise of four degrees [in temperatures] by the end of the century." He said that increased threats ranged from property damage to political risk – such as the implications for food security – and the economic impacts.

It could mean the insurance industry would need to hold more capital to protect against increased risk, he said.

Maynard said that while insurers typically arrange insurance cover for a stretch of one year, planners and building constructors would need to look ahead to the next 40 to 50 years.

Maynard said: "There is every indication that [storms] will get more extreme as the temperature rises." He noted that the report by Sir Nicholas Stern on the economics of climate change concluded that it was cheaper "to avoid it".

Lloyd's made a £516m loss in 2011 after paying out the largest catastrophe claims on record – caused by earthquakes in Japan and New Zealand, storms in the US, and floods in Thailand and Australia. The area flooded in Thailand was the size of Birmingham and it remained under water for a couple of months.

Since this year Lloyd's has been run by Inga Beale, who became chief executive of the company in January. The organisation, which started in a coffee house in 1688 where merchants insured ships and has evolved into a group of about 80 competing insurance syndicates, has insured a large range of items, from Keith Richards' fingers to satellites, as well as provided cover for homes and companies.

webTitle: Waitrose teams up with McGough in the hope verses will open purses

fields.bodyText: Waitrose is to unleash an unlikely weapon in the supermarkets' cut-throat battle for business when it anounces plans to display poetry throughout its stores as part of a year-long campaign which, it says, is aimed at reducing the drudgery of the regular shop. Initially a selection of lighthearted verses penned by the poet Roger McGough (already employed by the grocer as the voice of its TV ads) will appear in all 317 UK stores, from the fish counter to the fruit and vegetable section, and even on the mirrors of the customer toilets. The poet – known for short comic poems such as "It's a joy to be old. The dog dead and the car sold" – hopes that displaying poems in supermarkets might help to bring poetry to a wider audience. Selections – some brand new for Waitrose and others adaptations of his existing work – will appear on the ends of aisles and shelves, as well as on point-of-sale material including "wobblers" and on paper tray liners in its cafes. Excerpts of McGough's Keep Your Eyes Peeled will be displayed in fruit and veg sections, for example, while the new Tofu and the Tiger will appear alongside tofu and similar products. McGough told the Guardian: "It's about putting a smile on people's faces as they head for the fish fingers. Poetry doesn't just belong in the library or on the bookshelf – it can be equally at home on the supermarket shelf. Poems can celebrate the happy events in our lives as well as consoling us in the dark times. My verses, however, are more of a caress, a tickle, or a poke in the ribs." The award-winning poet has visited his local branch of Waitrose in East Sheen, London, to see at first hand how his poetry will be displayed in store. As well as displaying McGough's verses in the Year of Poetry campaign, the retailer is appealing for shoppers to write their own. Each month, six poems by customers will appear in stores alongside McGough's in Waitrose branches. After four months of winning poems, McGough will judge all 24, choosing a top three to be announced on National Poetry Day on 2 October. But senior managers, including managing director Mark Price, will be hoping that the poetry competition does not backfire along the lines of its social media experiment eighteen months ago. When it challenged shoppers to "finish the sentence: 'I shop at Waitrose because …' #WaitroseReasons" , it triggered a Twitter storm as internet jokers piled in to ridicule the brand for its posh image. 'Tofu and the Tiger' by Roger McGough for Waitrose If a tiger invites you home for tea And offers you tofu You can take it from me He's only pretending Look at those jaws Were they designed for chewing rice? And those claws For peeling bananas? Take my advice Stay calm, be polite. Eat up your tofu and ask for more When the feline is in the kitchen Make a bee-line for the door.

webTitle: AstraZeneca: we will have to look more closely at Pfizer's share price

fields.standfirst: Last week's proposal was merely a sighting-shot. When Pfizer gets serious its offer will be heavier on cash, but these are early days
fields.body:
Amid the political noise, the weakness in Pfizer's share price has received less attention than it should. Last Thursday the US group's shares were trading at $31.15 (£18.37), which was the price used in calculating the value of Friday's cash-plus-shares offer for AstraZeneca at £50. Yesterday, as Pfizer's shares dipped to $29 (£17), the value of the rejected terms fell to £47.50.

Last week's proposal was merely a sighting-shot. When Pfizer gets serious its offer will be heavier on cash, which was only one-third of the total last week. But Pfizer can't offer cash alone because flipping the tax domicile to the UK (crucial to the financial logic) requires AstraZeneca shareholders to own at least 20% of the combined new company on day one.

So Pfizer's share price will be important in this saga. Paper-backed mega-bids require momentum to keep the value of the offer rising and confidence high among the target's shareholders. That, roughly speaking, is how Vodafone forced the board of Mannesmann to capitulate back in 2000: the deal became unstoppable.

These are early days and Pfizer has plenty of cards to play, like talking up the potential cost savings (at the risk of more political grief in the UK) and putting a hard figure on the tax savings. But it can't be happy with a soggy start.

webTitle: More companies face shareholder rebellions over directors' pay

fields.bodyText: Shareholder rebellions over directors' pay continued when household goods group Reckitt Benckiser – which makes brands including Calgon, Dettol and Strepsils – and online grocer Ocado both faced revolts at their annual meetings. The votes follow similar rebellions at Pearson, AstraZeneca and Barclays. Nearly one-third of Reckitt's shareholders opposed its annual pay report, with 20% rejecting the separate pay policy outlining the company's bonus policy for the next three years. The company's pay framework handed its chief executive, Rakesh Kapoor, £6.7m last year, although that was slightly less than the previous year. Shareholder lobby group PIRC had urged investors to oppose the vote, saying: "Maximum potential payouts under all incentive schemes for the executives are considered excessive … The ratio of CEO pay compared to average employee pay has not been disclosed and is estimated to be 160:1, which is considered excessive." PIRC also objected to insufficient payout criteria and a golden hello scheme to compensate new executives for forfeiting pay deals from previous employers. PIRC described this as "inappropriate practice". Reckitt has a track record in upsetting its investors over pay, as in 2009, when its previous chief executive, Bart Becht, was handed £92m. Some 20% of Ocado shareholders voted against the online grocer's pay report. The rebellion centred on its "growth incentive plan", which awards free shares to directors depending on the company's share price. Later this month, chief executive Tim Steiner will be granted 4m shares, currently worth more than £12m. Two other directors will each receive 1m shares. The proposal had been "red-topped" by the Association of British Insurers, indicating serious concerns over the pay plan. The warning automatically triggers a no vote among some investment groups. A spokesman said Ocado had consulted its shareholders over the pay scheme and that it had the support of the majority.

webTitle: Barclays to cut up to 8,000 investment banking jobs

fields.standfirst: Bank boss Antony Jenkins to announce losses as he outlines plan to overhaul investment arm following criticism over bonuses
fields.body:
Barclays will announce on Thursday that it is cutting up to 8,000 investment banking roles – almost a third of the division's workforce – as it retreats from one of the most controversial parts of its business.

Antony Jenkins, the embattled Barclays chief executive, is to outline his plan to overhaul the investment bank on Thursday after facing fierce criticism for his decision to increase bonuses by 10% last year, when profits fell sharply.

In an announcement to the City, Jenkins is expected to explain how he intends to tackle the most troublesome parts of the investment bank – the traditional powerhouse of Barclays – to prove to investors that he can rein in costs and start to bolster the profitability of the organisation.

He has been under pressure since insisting that bonuses needed to rise last year to keep crucial staff and avoid a "death spiral" that might otherwise have occurred if they were allowed to leave.

But, in his latest strategy update – his third since taking the helm after Bob Diamond left in the wake of the Libor-rigging scandal – Jenkins is expected to signal the potential for fresh cuts in the investment banking arm, which employs 24,000 around the world, primarily in the City and Wall Street.

The jobs are not expected to go all at once, but spread over three years. Some are likely to have gone already or be in train as the bank has begun to scale back its vast commodities trading operation and end trading in so-called physical commodities such as agricultural produce.

The bank has already earmarked 12,000 job cuts for this year, with 7,000 of those in the UK. It is unclear how many of the latest round of 8,000 are on top of those earlier numbers.

Barclays has been targeting senior employees. Around 450 directors and managing directors have been made redundant in the first quarter, finance director Tushar Morzaria said on Tuesday, when the bank admitted that revenues in its investment bank had almost halved in the first three months of the year. The bank signalled that further senior roles would be axed in the run-up to June.

The fall in revenues perplexed City analysts after the decision to raise bonuses last year.

Some of the unwanted parts of the investment bank are expected to be placed in a non-core division – a so-called bad bank – with loss-making operations in continental Europe earmarked for sale.

The investment bank expanded rapidly after 2008, when Barclays bought the Wall Street operations of Lehman Brothers, although in recent days there has been speculation about large-scale resignations following the departure of Skip McGee, head of its US investment banking operations. He was the most senior banker remaining from the Lehman takeover and received £8.8m in shares in March.

Barclays' downturn in profits in the first quarter was largely caused by its commodities and bond trading operations, where regulators are reducing profitability by demanding that banks hold more capital and where volatility in markets means there is less appetite for trading.

As he put the finishing touches to his strategy review last month, Jenkins had already made clear that he intends to retain the investment banking operations of the bank.

He told shareholders at last month's annual meeting – where investors protested about last year's pay deals: "The future for Barclays will be as a strong, focused, international bank. And the investment bank will be an important part of that mix. A strong investment bank in Barclays is good for the business, good for shareholders, and good for Britain."

But he said that the "right shape and size" of the investment bank was a crucial consideration for his strategic review.

His review "will address issues underlying the performance challenges we have recently experienced, including positioning the investment bank for the new operating and regulatory environment," he said.

Other banks have been taking hits in their investment banking arms. On Wednesday HSBC was the latest, citing "challenging market conditions" as its profits fell 13% in the first quarter of the year. In the investment bank, profits fell by a fifth and are likely to remain subdued in the second quarter.

Jenkins has already let it be known that he expects the 140,000 global workforce of Barclays – which includes high street banking, investment banking and fund management – to fall to 100,000 over the years as new technology replaces jobs. This is also likely to have an impact on the number of branches. Of the 12,000 job cuts already announced, the 7,000 posts affected in the UK are not just in the investment bank but also in high street branches, where iPads are replacing employees.

Jenkins's bonus policies recently faced criticism from the former boss of investment bank JP Cazenove, Robert Pickering, who said investments would perpetuate the myth of the "death spiral".

"It is absolutely ingrained in the culture of these organisations and Mr Jenkins' antagonists at [the investment bank] in the US, having been schooled in the rough, tough world of Lehman Brothers, will be master exponents of the art form," Pickering wrote in the Financial Times.

webTitle: Lord Myners calls for radical overhaul of Co-operative Group

fields.bodyText: The Co-operative Group needs a radical boardroom overhaul if it is to survive the traumatic shocks of the past year, the City veteran charged with reforming the troubled chain of supermarkets, funeral homes and pharmacies has warned. Lord Myners, Labour's City minister during the banking crisis, described a "dysfunctional" board in which some directors did not know the difference between debits and credits and "clearly out of their depth when financial concepts and terminology are used". He said he realised within 30 minutes of his first board meeting in January that the board was not up to the job, with discussions ranging from "some want a dividend, some want low prices, some want to do social good and some want free-range chickens". Publishing a 180-page report, Myners said the board – currently made up of members of the co-operative movement such as nurses, farmers and public-sector workers – was "stuck in denial" over what he called a "near ruinous" failure of governance, which led to the near-collapse of its bank last year. None of them had quit – although some had been forced out – and he questioned why some of them remained. "This board is not competent to perform the duties expected of it," he said, as he called for the Financial Conduct Authority to broaden the scope of its investigation from the bank to the wider group. "Radical decisions on governance need to be taken soon … if the Co-op, as my mother knew it, is to be saved," said Myners. "The decision lies in the hands of elected democrats. I have done all I can do." Myners unexpectedly quit the Co-op board last month, but agreed to stay to complete his review. Making no apology for setting out in "stark terms" the need for urgent reform, he warned that bank lenders owed £1.4bn by the group – which lost £2.5bn last year – could force fire sales of its prized businesses to get their money back, or increase the borrowing rate they charge on their loans. Myners said the Co-op would not go bust as it could always sell its funeral homes business for £1bn if necessary. His attacks on the current members of the board sparked warnings that it might now be even more difficult for his reforms to be passed at the annual meeting in 10 days' time. In heated exchanges at the Treasury select committee, Andy Love, a Labour and Co-op MP, questioned Myners about democratic representation of the members under his proposals. But officials at Unite – concerned about the 90,000 employees of the group – urged members to back Myners as he was "the only game in town at the moment that can deliver a future for the group and our members". Chairman of Guardian Media Group until 2008, Myners warned that one idea of winding the Co-op into a charitable foundation to fund its social purposes could leave little cash behind. Setting out his plans for reform to the Co-op's current governance structure of "labyrinthine complexity", Myners also called for an investigation by the City regulator into a report the Co-op commissioned from investigators Kroll into leaks from the boardroom . He also suggested a review of the £1 membership fee – one and a half week's salary when the Co-op was set up in the 19th century – the equivalent to £675 now. Myners first published an outline of his reforms in March after chief executive Euan Sutherland walked out after just 10 months, branding the group ungovernable after his £6.6m pay deal was leaked to the Observer. "The loss of Euan Sutherland is a catastrophe for the Co-op. He was the right man and forced out by some people who should lower their heads in shame because they certainly did not behave in a way that Co-operative values and principles suggest that they should," said Myners. His reforms are little changed from the original, which recommended replacing the current board of 15 representatives from the regional boards – which represent the 8 million members who own 78% of the group – and five from the 22 independent societies that own the remainder. A national membership council would be set up and a one-member, one-vote system created rather than the current system, which he says is more like one vote per 10,000 members. Myners, appointed in December, insisted he had not quit because of opposition to his proposals. "I have myself witnessed repeated instances where there has been a denial of responsibility, corrosive suspicion, deliberate delay and a practice of hiding behind values in order to deflect or stifle criticism and protect self-interest. It was the combination of these factors, when discussing the approval of this year's accounts, that obliged me to resign as a director of the group after only four months," Myners said. The board members had been waiting for him to sign the accounts so they would have the confidence to sign them too, he said. He was defiant as he published his reforms: "It would be completely irresponsible to change my diagnosis because the prescription is unpalatable and hard for some elected members to accept." The annual meeting of the Co-op is due to vote on resolutions related to his reforms on 17 May and Myners recommended the reforms be adopted by next year's annual meeting, with the new boardroom structure in place by November this year. He said he hoped the Co-op would allow the media entry to this month's AGM.

webTitle: Supermarket price war is a 'skirmish' at most, says Sainsbury's outgoing boss

fields.bodyText: Outgoing Sainsbury's boss Justin King has denied that a new supermarket price war is breaking out, dismissing the aggressive price cuts announced by rival supermarkets as a "skirmish". "Price skirmishes are an ever-present part of this industry," King said as the supermarket reported a 5% increase in underlying profits to £798m. Speaking in the wake of £300m of price cuts announced by rival Morrisons last week – the first part of a £1bn move on prices which will halve its profits – King said: "I don't want to play the old-man card but I've been around for 30 years and seen plenty of this type of activity in years gone by. We always say we will look at the detail and keep doing the things that have served our business well." King, who was presenting his last set of annual results, will hand over the baton to his number two, Mike Coupe, at the company's AGM in July. The changing of the guard comes at a time of major upheaval as the big four supermarkets battle the rise of discounters Aldi and Lidl at the same time as Britons increasingly shun the big weekly shop in favour of online transactions and more frequent shopping at convenience stores. King is credited with turning Sainsbury's around by improving its products and shops, opening convenience stores and overhauling supply systems. The group increased sales throughout the recession but announced its first setback in sales for nine years in March. Some analysts believe profits could fall this year after Tesco, Morrisons and Asda announced big price cuts. New industry data from Kantar Worldpanel showed grocery sales growing at their slowest rate for at least 11 years over the last three months as price cuts and easing food price inflation take their toll of the industry's health. King batted away the suggestion he was "getting out at the top". "I am retaining a significant shareholding in the company as an indication of my confidence in the future," he said. "I believe the business can go from strength to strength … Mike is not assuming the reins on prices; he's actually been responsible for that for the last nine years." Coupe said Sainsbury's had more weapons than simply matching competitors' prices. "Of course, we will match our competitors' prices toe to toe, but our brand is built on differentiation," he said, pointing to ethical commitments such as British sourcing, paying a fair price to dairy farmers and selling "cage-free" eggs. "If you go back to 2007/2008 pretty much every commentator had us as most likely to fail in the economic downturn but it's not an exaggeration to say that we've been far and away the best-performing grocer in the last six years, and that's because we believe what we do for customers is unique." The Kantar Worldpanel data showed Sainsbury's lost market share in the last three months with 16.6% of the market compared with 16.8% a year ago. The picture was much worse for Tesco, which saw its share drop to 28.7% – compared with 30% a year ago – and Morrisons, down from 11.6% to 11%, as both retailers recorded a fall in actual sales. "There are clear signs that the major supermarkets are reviewing their strategies in the face of increasing competition," said Kantar Worldpanel director Edward Garner. "We're now seeing the big four moving away from 'here today, gone tomorrow' promotions and toward everyday low prices. Lower prices across the board is great for shoppers, but has driven down market growth to its lowest level in 11 years." The increase in profits was the weakest of King's reign but compares with declines at both Tesco and Morrisons. Sainsbury's like-for-like sales were flat, and a similar outcome is expected this year. Like its rivals, the grocer is cutting back spending on new stores and plans to open 750,000 sq ft of new space this year, down from 1 million sq ft. Shore Capital analyst Darren Shirley said the industry was in a "considerable state of flux", with profit margins coming under increasing pressure. "To date we have believed that Sainsbury has a relatively differentiated offer, which acts as a barrier to the worst excesses of direct competition," he said. "However, at this juncture we're not so sure."

webTitle: Lord Myners testifies to MPs on Co-op's failings -- business live

fields.standfirst:
• Lord Paul Myners tells the Treasury Committee that the Co-op board isn't up to the job...
  • ...and riven with conflicts of interest
  • Myners Report demands radical overhaul
  • Lunchtime Summary
  • Former Co-op Bank chairman fined for drugs possession
fields.body:
6.01pm BST

Summary: Lord Myners tells MPs that Co-op's board isn't up to the job

What did we learn from Lord Myners appearance at the Treasury Committee? (highlights start here)?

Understandably, much of the hearing focused on evidence we'd already heard this morning, or was explained in his report (still online, here)

Myners took the opportunity to rip into the inadequacies of the Co-op Board again (did one member really think rented shops could be sold off to raise funds?!). None of them, he said, had the abilities needed to run such a company - with one board member's experience extending as far as the local golf club.

He said no board members had the skills to serve effectively, and rejected notion that they could be trained up to the mark - if such a course existed, there would be a stampede.

He even blamed their incompetence on his decision to quit Co-op after just three months -- saying board members didn't have the skills to appraise the Group's financial reports. And reiterated that the resignation of Euan Sutherland (in a row over his pay packet) was a bitter blow.

Many MPs, particularly on the Conservative side of the committee, appeared to welcome and support the report.

But Myners did face criticism, from Labour and Co-operative MP Andy Love, who accused him of failing to recognise the point of the co-operative movement. Those values could be destroyed if Myners plan is implemented, Love claimed - a suggestion the ex-City minister rejected.



Myners agreed that there was a 'cosy cabal' at the heart of the Co-op, who didn't want to give up their power and pay. But the tangled web of conflicts of interest must be shattered, he insisted. It can't be right to have people serving on the board of the Co-op, and the Co-operative Party, if one is funding the other.....

Myners raised the stakes ahead of the AGM on May 17, saying that regulators could be forced to send inspectors into the Co-op if his recommendations are rejected.

He made some intriguing political comments, some apparently aimed at George Osborne. Myners claimed the present government had pushed for the Project Verde deal, and then argued that the Group shouldn't be regulated as a bank if the branch sales had gone through.

He also denied that the Labour government, in which he served, had pushed for the ill-fated merger with Britannia Building Society.

Myners argued that the Co-op Group should cut its funding of affiliated bodies, including the Co-operative party, and put all political donations to a full vote. PWC are investigating all the Co-op's donations -- we will see that report, won't we?....

But overall, the hearing covered plenty of familiar ground -- no surprise, given Myners has been on the airways and most news websites since 7am.

And that's a good moment to wrap up for the night. Cheers. GW



Updated at 6.15pm BST

5.34pm BST

Here's a pithy explanation of the changes Lord Myners is proposing, via Reuters:

Myners said the Co-op should create a new streamlined board led by a chairman with no previous association with the group, six or seven independent non-executive directors and two executive directors.

Myners also recommended a National Membership Council be set up, consisting of about 50 individuals, including around 10 employees. This council would elect a steering committee of 12 members including representatives from independent societies.

In addition he proposed all Co-op members be given the right to vote on the election of board members, the right to attend general meetings and to approve significant transactions.

5.21pm BST

My colleague Nils Pratley has analysed Lord Myners report, and concludes that the Co-operative Group cannot risk ignoring its recommendations, as it famously did when Hugh Gaitskell urged reform in the 1950s.

Here's a flavour:

Being led by eager, earnest but unqualified amateurs is no way to run an organisation with 90,000 staff and a turnover of £12bn when the main competitors are fierce beasts like Tesco, Sainsbury's, Asda and Aldi. The report contains an extraordinary quote from an anonymous board member: "In a democracy, if I am elected and not adequately trained, then is it my fault?"

Yes, it is, actually. You shouldn't have gone for a job on the main board in the first place and you should recognise that part of the responsibility for the Co-op's financial condition lies at your door. It is astonishing that mass resignations from the boardroom have not followed the £2.5bn loss and the accumulation of heavy debts. Myners names no names but is all too easy to believe there really are directors who are confused by the difference between a creditor and debtor.

More here: Co-op can't limp on for another 55 years: back the Myners reforms

4.51pm BST

4.48pm BST

Speaking of Pfizer/AstraZeneca, the CEOs of both companies will be quizzed by parliament's Business, Innovation and Skills committee next Tuesday. They will also hear from the heads of the Unite and GMB unions.

The next day, the Science and Technology committee will have its say (as explained at 2.18pm)

Updated at 4.48pm BST

4.35pm BST

Here's a video clip of David Cameron answering questions on the other hot business issue of the moment -- Pfizer's takeover bid for AstraZeneca:

4.34pm BST

Finally (as the division bells ring out to summon MPs to a vote), Lib Dem John Thurso asks Myners whether the committee can separate the question of the Co-op's failings from the question of the future of the co-operative movement?

Yes, Myners says.

And with that, the session is over as the Treasury Committee's finest head to the lobby.

4.32pm BST

Myners warns that there is "a tangled conflict of interest" at the heart of the Co-op, contributing to its woes.

Some board members also serve on the board of the Co-operative Party (to whom it donates money), while others (the independent members) can be running a store just a few hundred yards from a Co-op supermarket, so face their competitors across the boardroom table.

Oh, missed this line about the folly of the Project Verde deal, but the Telegraph caught it:

Updated at 4.54pm BST

4.26pm BST

4.25pm BST

Myners: If Co-op rejects change, regulators could be forced to act

Should the regulators take a closer look at the conduct of the Bank board?

Lord Myners says that in his younger days, people talked about the DTI inspectors being sent into a troubled company.

Regulators could appoint an inspector to examine the conduct of the Co-op's board, yes. But that would be undesirable, costly, and distracting.

He runs through an alphabet soup of existing inquiries into the Co-op. Another one isn't needed.

BUT....if the Co-op ignores the need for change, I don't think the regulator could ignore the problem, Myners adds.

If you reject change, it will be forced upon you, he says. But the Co-op should want to reform itself.

4.21pm BST

Myners says the Co-op Group needs to sell assets to reduce its debt.

It must also cut the money it gives to affiliated parties, including the Co-operative Party, he says.

Myners has recommended that a firm of accountants examines the whole area of funding - PWC are now on the case. I have asked for their report to be released to the whole membership, not just the boardroom, he says. The Co-op needs to be open and transparent.

Are you saying that the political donations should be put to the vote at an AGM?

Yes, says Myners. The current process is deeply flawed and undemocratic.

4.19pm BST

Has the reduction of the Co-op's stake in its own bank, to 20%, removed its 'baleful' influence on the division, asks David Ruffley MP.

Myners says he mainly focused on the Group, once he discovered the full scale of the problems at its core.

4.16pm BST

Committee member Brooks Newmark tweets that Lord Myners is giving a "devastating" account of the Co-op's failings:

Indeed....

4.13pm BST

Back to the Co-op Bank -- MPs have cited the example of the Rochdale Pioneers (hurrah!), who were driven by the need to satisfy demands that weren't being met by the market.

Banking is not an area of unmet need today, Myners suggests.

Andrew Tyrie MP calls him up on this -- the committee has heard plenty of evidence that people can't get decent current accounts, or even find a good bank in their area.

Are you sure there' s no unmet demand, m'Lord?

Myners says he has pondered the causes of problems in Britain's banks for a long time - and whether lack of supply was a factor.

He reckons there may be unmet demand for, say, ethical banking - but not for more bricks and mortar branches.

Myners also denies that the Co-op's problems today means the organisations' founding principles are dead.

I am an enthusiastic supporter of the concept of co-operation and mutualisation, he insists.

4.08pm BST

Myners reckons that in 1950, the Co-op Group would have been worth as much as Sainsbury, Tesco, Asda and Morrisons put together.

4.08pm BST

How did the Co-op Group lose half its value since 2010?

Myners explains that, on top of the bank losses, it suffered from bad decisions such as keeping hundreds of empty stores.

This is an alarming tale; one board member reckoned they were an asset that could be sold off - Myners had to explain they were a liability, and Co-op was paying rent above the market rate - so couldn't shift them.

It also suffered from over-distribution, he adds.

4.05pm BST

Myners says that the merger with Britannia Building Society in 2009 caused huge destruction of value -- a point also made by the Kelly Report into the Co-op last week (probing the Co-op Crisis is turning into its own industry).

You were a minister at the time, though, Lord Myners -- did you help push the deal through?

"Radical decisions on governance need to be taken soon – and with resolution – if the Co-op, as my mother knew it, is to be saved," the 66-year-old said. "The decision lies in the hands of elected democrats. I have done all I can do."

Myners, who dramatically quit the Co-op last month, also accused the Co-op's top staff of shying away from the near disaster at the group, which lost control of its own Banking division after running up a £1.5bn capital blak hole.

He says:

I would say that the Group Board and many on the Regional Boards are still stuck in denial over this near ruinous failure of governance, whereas the vast majority of ordinary members feel justified anger.

MPs on the Treasury Committee will quiz Lord Myners over his report this afternoon, from around 3.15pm.

He'll also be holding a conference call to discuss the report, from 8am.

I'll be tracking the reaction to the report, along with other news through the day as usual...

fields.bodyText: What did we learn from Lord Myners appearance at the Treasury Committee? (highlights start here)? Understandably, much of the hearing focused on evidence we'd already heard this morning, or was explained in his report (still online, here) Myners took the opportunity to rip into the inadequacies of the Co-op Board again (did one member really think rented shops could be sold off to raise funds?!). None of them, he said, had the abilities needed to run such a company - with one board member's experience extending as far as the local golf club. He said no board members had the skills to serve effectively, and rejected notion that they could be trained up to the mark - if such a course existed, there would be a stampede. He even blamed their incompetence on his decision to quit Co-op after just three months -- saying board members didn't have the skills to appraise the Group's financial reports. And reiterated that the resignation of Euan Sutherland (in a row over his pay packet) was a bitter blow. Many MPs, particularly on the Conservative side of the committee, appeared to welcome and support the report. But Myners did face criticism, from Labour and Co-operative MP Andy Love, who accused him of failing to recognise the point of the co-operative movement. Those values could be destroyed if Myners plan is implemented, Love claimed - a suggestion the ex-City minister rejected. Myners agreed that there was a 'cosy cabal' at the heart of the Co-op, who didn't want to give up their power and pay. But the tangled web of conflicts of interest must be shattered, he insisted. It can't be right to have people serving on the board of the Co-op, and the Co-operative Party, if one is funding the other..... Myners raised the stakes ahead of the AGM on May 17, saying that regulators could be forced to send inspectors into the Co-op if his recommendations are rejected. He made some intriguing political comments, some apparently aimed at George Osborne. Myners claimed the present government had pushed for the Project Verde deal, and then argued that the Group shouldn't be regulated as a bank if the branch sales had gone through. He also denied that the Labour government, in which he served, had pushed for the ill-fated merger with Britannia Building Society. Myners argued that the Co-op Group should cut its funding of affiliated bodies, including the Co-operative party, and put all political donations to a full vote. PWC are investigating all the Co-op's donations -- we will see that report, won't we?.... But overall, the hearing covered plenty of familiar ground -- no surprise, given Myners has been on the airways and most news websites since 7am. And that's a good moment to wrap up for the night. Cheers. GW Here's a pithy explanation of the changes Lord Myners is proposing, via Reuters: Myners said the Co-op should create a new streamlined board led by a chairman with no previous association with the group, six or seven independent non-executive directors and two executive directors. Myners also recommended a National Membership Council be set up, consisting of about 50 individuals, including around 10 employees. This council would elect a steering committee of 12 members including representatives from independent societies. In addition he proposed all Co-op members be given the right to vote on the election of board members, the right to attend general meetings and to approve significant transactions. My colleague Nils Pratley has analysed Lord Myners report, and concludes that the Co-operative Group cannot risk ignoring its recommendations, as it famously did when Hugh Gaitskell urged reform in the 1950s. Here's a flavour: Being led by eager, earnest but unqualified amateurs is no way to run an organisation with 90,000 staff and a turnover of £12bn when the main competitors are fierce beasts like Tesco, Sainsbury's, Asda and Aldi. The report contains an extraordinary quote from an anonymous board member: "In a democracy, if I am elected and not adequately trained, then is it my fault?" Yes, it is, actually. You shouldn't have gone for a job on the main board in the first place and you should recognise that part of the responsibility for the Co-op's financial condition lies at your door. It is astonishing that mass resignations from the boardroom have not followed the £2.5bn loss and the accumulation of heavy debts. Myners names no names but is all too easy to believe there really are directors who are confused by the difference between a creditor and debtor. More here: Co-op can't limp on for another 55 years: back the Myners reforms Speaking of Pfizer/AstraZeneca, the CEOs of both companies will be quizzed by parliament's Business, Innovation and Skills committee next Tuesday. They will also hear from the heads of the Unite and GMB unions. The next day, the Science and Technology committee will have its say (as explained at 2.18pm) Here's a video clip of David Cameron answering questions on the other hot business issue of the moment -- Pfizer's takeover bid for AstraZeneca: Finally (as the division bells ring out to summon MPs to a vote), Lib Dem John Thurso asks Myners whether the committee can separate the question of the Co-op's failings from the question of the future of the co-operative movement? Yes, Myners says. And with that, the session is over as the Treasury Committee's finest head to the lobby. Myners warns that there is "a tangled conflict of interest" at the heart of the Co-op, contributing to its woes. Some board members also serve on the board of the Co-operative Party (to whom it donates money), while others (the independent members) can be running a store just a few hundred yards from a Co-op supermarket, so face their competitors across the boardroom table. Oh, missed this line about the folly of the Project Verde deal, but the Telegraph caught it: Should the regulators take a closer look at the conduct of the Bank board? Lord Myners says that in his younger days, people talked about the DTI inspectors being sent into a troubled company. Regulators could appoint an inspector to examine the conduct of the Co-op's board, yes. But that would be undesirable, costly, and distracting. He runs through an alphabet soup of existing inquiries into the Co-op. Another one isn't needed. BUT....if the Co-op ignores the need for change, I don't think the regulator could ignore the problem, Myners adds. If you reject change, it will be forced upon you, he says. But the Co-op should want to reform itself. Myners says the Co-op Group needs to sell assets to reduce its debt. It must also cut the money it gives to affiliated parties, including the Co-operative Party, he says. Myners has recommended that a firm of accountants examines the whole area of funding - PWC are now on the case. I have asked for their report to be released to the whole membership, not just the boardroom, he says. The Co-op needs to be open and transparent. Are you saying that the political donations should be put to the vote at an AGM? Yes, says Myners. The current process is deeply flawed and undemocratic. Has the reduction of the Co-op's stake in its own bank, to 20%, removed its 'baleful' influence on the division, asks David Ruffley MP. Myners says he mainly focused on the Group, once he discovered the full scale of the problems at its core. Committee member Brooks Newmark tweets that Lord Myners is giving a "devastating" account of the Co-op's failings: Indeed.... Back to the Co-op Bank -- MPs have cited the example of the Rochdale Pioneers (hurrah!), who were driven by the need to satisfy demands that weren't being met by the market. Banking is not an area of unmet need today, Myners suggests. Andrew Tyrie MP calls him up on this -- the committee has heard plenty of evidence that people can't get decent current accounts, or even find a good bank in their area. Are you sure there' s no unmet demand, m'Lord? Myners says he has pondered the causes of problems in Britain's banks for a long time - and whether lack of supply was a factor. He reckons there may be unmet demand for, say, ethical banking - but not for more bricks and mortar branches. Myners also denies that the Co-op's problems today means the organisations' founding principles are dead. I am an enthusiastic supporter of the concept of co-operation and mutualisation, he insists. Myners reckons that in 1950, the Co-op Group would have been worth as much as Sainsbury, Tesco, Asda and Morrisons put together. How did the Co-op Group lose half its value since 2010? Myners explains that, on top of the bank losses, it suffered from bad decisions such as keeping hundreds of empty stores. This is an alarming tale; one board member reckoned they were an asset that could be sold off - Myners had to explain they were a liability, and Co-op was paying rent above the market rate - so couldn't shift them. It also suffered from over-distribution, he adds. Myners says that the merger with Britannia Building Society in 2009 caused huge destruction of value -- a point also made by the Kelly Report into the Co-op last week (probing the Co-op Crisis is turning into its own industry). You were a minister at the time, though, Lord Myners -- did you help push the deal through? We were at the height of the banking crisis at the time, Myners replies -- there were bigger issues to deal with. But could Co-op board members have been starstruck when they met Labour politicians at party conferences and suchlike - and been encouraged to do the deal? Sheer speculation, Myners replies. No more than the speculation that the current government pushed for the Lloyds branch deal? Myners says ministers have admitted they facilitated the Verde deal (not the same as pushing it though). George Osborne even welcomed it. MPs say they were astonished by a recent interview on Newsnight by Paul Flowers, in which he painted a quite different picture of the ill-fated Project Verde (the bid to take over hundreds of Lloyds branches). Flowers told Newsnight that he came under considerable pressure from the government to get the Project Verde deal done -- something ministers have denied. Mark Garnier says Myners has painted a picture of a parish council running the Co-op Group. How did this impact the management of Co-op Bank? Myners says that there was little practical difference between the Group and the Bank. City regulators focused on the Bank board - they should have paid more attention to the Group board. If they had, they would have had more concerns, he argues. Myners says it was a mistake not to treat the Co-op Group as a financial entity for regulatory purposes if Verde had gone through -- rather than a funerals and pharmacies chain with a banking arm. He says the regulator should not have been dissuaded, as a letter from the Treasury suggests it was, from paying more attention to the Group. In reply to John Mann MP, Lord Myners explains that the Co-op's governance problems were created when the Co-operative Retail Society and the Co-operative Wholesale Society merged in 2000. That merger led to the loss of one member one vote, and the removal of the right of all members to attend the AGM, he says. Mann, who serves on a Co-op committee himself, asks Myners if he is saying that people are too cosy in these positions, and that it's a cosy cabal looking after each other? You're right, says Myners, saying the inexorable rise of executive pay has contributed to inequality in the UK (Myners, incidentally, has chaired Guardian Media Group, Land Securities and Marks & Spencer over the years). Mann cites an example of a Co-op meeting where he warned the Group to beware financial problems, but his fellow members were more interested in discussing plastic bags. You were right to caution them about the need to take the situation seriously, Myners replied. The Co-op spent too much time worrying about the size of chickens coops, and not enough on the Big Picture. Andy Love, Labour and Co-operative MP, and Lord Myners now trade blows over the report. Love reads from a recent Financial Times article criticising Myners' review, which warns that his recommendations were not compatible with co-operative values. Myners says the FT will revisit its verdict now the full report has been released. Love hits back -- saying Myners has failed to recognise the Co-op's unique feature and its democratic structure. By recommending dismantling it, he risks undermining the favourable parts of his report. In increasingly tetchy exchange, Myners says that the Co-op was paying a dividend worth £1bn in today's money. It now pays no dividend. Love reiterates that ditching the link to regional and local areas will weaken the co-operative values. What's undemocratic about One Member, One Vote, Myners asks. There is nothing in here that is anti mutual or anti-co-operative. Myners claims that most Co-operative members support him -- the problem lies with those at the top, who aren't keen to relinquish power and give up their fees. Has life been tough at the Co-op since you resigned? Myners jokes that he has reasonably tough skin - reminding MPs that he appeared before this committee to explain Sir Fred Goodwin's pension (signed off by Myners as City minister). He also shows some sympathy with Co-op veterans, faced with an outsider like Myners who has been making uncomfortable truths, loudly. He adds that the Co-op's banks will force it to take further action to rebuild its financial health. Jesse Norman MP asks about the leaking of confidential information from the Co-op. Myners replies that Co-op has been "beset by leaks" for the last year. That has caused serious damage, including driving out a "first class CEO" in Euan Sutherland. The board asked investigation firm Krollto look into the system, and that led them to ask Mr Stuart Ramsey to leave. Myners cited the Co-op's PPI misselling compensation as another sign that it wasn't being run properly. Myners explains that the Co-op board had a flawed belief that the management were "on tap, not on top". One reckoned they couldn't sack Co-op Bank CEO Peter Marks because he was making the big profits. That, Myners says, is often a reason to take a very close look at someone.... He also reiterates that the board lacked experience - one member had only served on a golf club before.... Conservative MP Brooks Newmark asks Lord Myners to define the skills needed for a successful director. They should stick to their ground, be polite to others, knowledgeable about business issues, and understand the context in which the business is operating, Myners replies And what testing was there at the Co-op to assess if board members have this skill set? Myners explains that there wasn't any. OK, so what programmes were run to get board members up to scratch? Myners explains that if such a programme existed, that would turn raw recruits into boardroom warriers capable of running a company big enough to get into the FTSE100, it would be overwhelmed. It's a flawed belief that such programmes could work, he says. After all, Harvard doesn't tell its MBA graduates that they can run a big company. Having got a Harvard MBA, they certainly make you think you can, Newmark jokes.  Newmark also likened the situation at the Co-op to "A Perfect Storm". The Co-op can recruit talented non-executive directors to serve on its board, Myners insisted. Reminder - this chart from his report shows how little experience the Co-op board has. After a long decline, the Co-op is at an inflection point -- if it takes the right decisions now, it can enjoy a much brighter future, Myners concludes. Myners explains that his solution is a PLC-plus board -- a highly qualified board, holding the executive to account, complemented by a national council who is charged with checking that the board is doing what it should (acting like shareholders, effectively) He denies that it's a cunning plan to get his friends onto the Co-op board. He also repeats that the Co-op's system, in which board members rose to the top through serving on area and regional boards, was deeply flawed -- creating a small pool of potential talent, and forcing people to resign if they moved from one region to another. Myners is repeating some of the points from this morning's press call -- no-one on the Co-op board had proper business experience, or understood basic financial terms. Andrew Tyrie kicks off the hearing by asking Lord Myners why he resigned from the Co-op board. Myners explains that he became increasingly exasperated by the amateurish approach followed by the Co-op board. He believes that some of the directors hasn't studied its financial reports properly, and were hoping to 'slipstream' him by waiting for the former City minister to sign them off first. Lord Myners is appearing before the Treasury Committee now to discuss his report into the Co-op - it's being streamed here. The Russian stock market is rallying, and so is the ruble, after President Putin called on separatists on Eastern Ukraine to postpone their referendum on independence. Putin said Russia will do "all it can" to resolve the Ukraine crisis and will take a "most positive" approach to international piece efforts. Putin also said Russia had withdrawn its forces from the border with Ukraine, according to the Interfax news agency. A sign that the escalating tensions in Eastern Ukraine could now calm? It's sent the MICEX index surging 4.5% (see graph above), and pushed the ruble up 1% against the US dollar. More details of Lord Myners' call for a wholesale shake-up at of the Co-op's incompetent board -- apparently he thinks only only one member should stay on. Would the Treasury Committee be kind enough to ask him whom, at 3.15pm?.... Parliament's Science and Technology committee has announced it will take evidence from AstraZeneca CEO Pascal Soriot on May 14. They will also hear from two senior Pfizer executives - Mikael Dolsten, President, Worldwide Research and Development, and Rod Mackenzie, Group Senior Vice President. Science minister David Willetts is also appearing. Andrew Miller MP, Chair of the Science and Technology Committee, said: “AstraZeneca is one of the bastions of the UK’s world-leading pharmaceutical sector. It supports around 30,000 jobs, many of them highly skilled, and is an important component of our scientific landscape. Next week’s hearing will be an opportunity for us to scrutinise the pledges on research and development being made as part of this potential takeover and pose questions about how the Government will ensure that these commitments are met.” Here's the announcement: Proposed takeover of AstraZeneca All that winter snow was bad for productivity, but it did give Americans more time to sit at home and play addictive games on their phones and tablets. Maybe that's why social and mobile game King Digital reported such strong results today -- with profits doubling in the first quarter of 2014. The firm, famous for Candy Crush Saga, reported strong demand for its new game Farm Heroes. The company floated on Wall Street in late March -- shares are up 3.4% in pre-market trading to $19.41, but still below its IPO price of $22.50. Over to America, where the latest productivity figures confirm that the US economy took a nasty jolt over the winter, when bad weather gripped the country. Output per worker fell by 1.7% (on an annual rate) in the first quarter of 2014, the first decline in a year. That wipes out most of the 2.3% rise in productivity seen in the last three months of 2013. And labour costs jumped by 4.2%, suggesting firms were forced to pay more to staff to overcome the ice and blizzards that struck America in January. Last week, GDP data showed that the US economy barely grew in the first three months of 2014 - some economists reckon it actually contracted. Reminder - Lord Myners is due before the Treasury Committee this afternoon to discuss his proposals for the Co-op Group, from around 3.15pm. He's been a busy bee -- telling Sky News that the Co-op needs an "almost total" clear out. Back to the Co-op, and Professor John Thanassoulis of Warwick University isn't convinced by Lord Myners' proposal for a new governance structure. Myners wants the Co-op Group board to be made up of executive office holders and non-executive independent members. Thanassoulis fears that it is too close to a traditional PLC board set-up (something Myners has been denying this morning), and is not the best way to guarantee uphold co-operative values. He sais: This is the key proposal and it eschews the learning from all other governance models outside those of the Plc. If members do not have a seat at the top table then the independent directors will be almost unassailable. Independent directors are liable to be chosen from those experienced in running supermarkets/banks/pharmacies from the private sector. Those who have made a career successfully defending shareholder interests are liable to behave in a similar way on the co-operative board. "Lord Myners is right that a Board needs talented individuals who are not corrupt. But the challenge surely is to create a governance structure whereby this is achieved. Here's another flavour of David Cameron's comments on Pfizer: "The commitments that have been made so far are encouraging...But let me absolutely clear, I'm not satisfied. I want more but the way to get more is to engage." Another question about Pfizer at PMQs - about whether AstraZeneca jobs are at risk if a takeover goes through. David Cameron repeats that it was "absolutely right" to ask the cabinet secretary to engage with Pfizer. He says the pledges made by the US company last week - including completing AstraZeneca's plan to move its headquarters and research facilities to Cambridge by 2016 -- are encouraging. Over in Parliament, David Cameron and Ed Miliband have clashed over Pfizer's attempts to take control of AstraZeneca. Miliband warned that a takeover would have serious long-term implications for UK jobs, exports and science, and asked whether the government will apply the public interest test to the deal. Cameron doesn't say whether he'd rule in, or rule out, using the test. He then defends the government's decision to speak to Pfizer. We make "no apology" for engaging with Pfizer -- we're fighting for British science, rather than sitting on the sidelines, he says. Andy Sparrow has full coverage of Prime Minister's Questions in his liveblog: Cameron and Miliband at PMQs: Politics live blog So, how did the Co-op end up with a such a dysfunctional board, lacking the competence to run it? Lord Myners' report explains in some detail how the Co-op's three-tier electoral structure is an anomaly -- people are elected to the Area Committee, then the regional board, and then to the Group board. That means: 1) a small pool of possible candidates to run the business 2) Constant pressure on those who reach the board, who must regularly be re-elected to each tier of the group. 3) Potential individuals with “skills but not time” – particularly younger members – are put off from trying to rise to the top, as serving the Co-op can be an almost full-time job (as explained at 9.44am, you can be paid over £40,000 per year for it, too) Myners also argues that this has left the Co-op with a serious skills gap, compared to the non-executive directors (NEDs) on the boards of rival companies: Myners also accuses some board members of a casual disregard for their own weaknesses, writing: As one Group Board director put it: “In a democracy, if I am elected and not adequately trained, then is it my fault?” Here's Reuters' story about the PM's spokesman's comments re AstraZeneca: Britain should consider whether existing takeover laws giving ministers power to intervene in deals could be applied to U.S. drugmaker Pfizer's approach for London-listed AstraZeneca, Prime Minister David Cameron's spokesman said on Wednesday. Cameron's spokesman told reporters that the Prime Minister agreed with Business Secretary Vince Cable who on Tuesday said the government needed to consider whether a 'public interest test' should be applied to any potential takeover. Reuters is reporting that David Cameron's spokesman has agreed that the government should consider whether a takeover of AstraZeneca is in the public interest (presumably at this morning's lobby briefing). BRITISH PM SPOKESMAN SAYS AGREES OF NEED TO CONSIDER IF PUBLIC INTEREST TEST APPLIES TO POTENTIAL PFIZER TAKEOVER OF ASTRAZENECA As if Lord Myners didn't have enough on his plate with the Co-op, he's also found time to weigh in on Pfizer's attempt to take control of AstraZeneca. Myners told ITV News it was a mistake for prime minister David Cameron to act as a "cheerleader" for Pfizer, and believes the authorities should assess whether the bid is in the national interest. Today's economic data is a rather mixed bag, including a shock drop in activity across Japan's private sector. Markit's monthly "composite PMI" index, which tracks output across thousands of Japanese firms, tumbled to 46.3 in April, down from 52.8 in March. That shows a pretty sharp drop in activity (the 50-point mark separates expansion from contraction). Analysts are blaming the hike in Japan's sales tax at the start of April, from 5% to 8%, which risks undermining prime minister Abe's efforts to inflate the Japanese economy and stimulate growth. Separately, German factory orders slid 2.8% in March, suggesting its economy isn't rattling along quite as quickly as expected. Domestic orders fell by 0.6% ,while foreign orders dropped by 4.6% - and by 9.4% from the eurozone countries. The Ukraine crisis is taking some of the blame, given Germany's close business links with Russia. The German economy warned there could be further disruption, as firms temporarily hold back from placing new orders "due to current geopolitical events." HSBC has become the latest bank to report a drop in profits, as tough conditions in foreign exchange and bond trading dented its earnings. The bank reported a 20% drop in pre-tax profits for the first three months of 2014, to $6.785bn, and warned that customer activity stayed “muted” in April. Strip out one-off items, and profits were down 13%. Chief executive Stuart Gulliver said:: “Global banking and markets had a relatively good performance and we grew our market share in several product categories. Commercial Banking saw revenue growth but, in our Principal Retail Banking and Wealth Management business, revenues were impacted by changes in incentive plans and product pricing.” Our Sean Farrell is on the HSBC conference call now, tweeting the key points: Back to Leeds Crown Court, where my colleague Helen Pidd reports that the reverend Paul Flowers has pleaded guilty to three charges of possessing drugs. The former Co-op Bank chairman been fined £400, and ordered to pay £125 in costs. Flowers was charged with two counts of possession of Class A drugs – cocaine and methamphetamine – and one count of possession of the Class C drug ketamine. Onto other business. And Britain's love affair with new cars remains undimmed, according to new data this morning. The Society for Motor Manufacturers and Traders reports that sales were 8% higher than a year ago in April, at 176,280. Mike Hawes, SMMT chief executive, said Britain's strengthening economy was driving the market: “This marks 26 consecutive months of growth as GDP continues to pick up, inflation falls and wage levels improve." This has prompted the SMMT to ramp up its forecast for sales in 2014 as a whole, from 2.3m to over 2.4m. Hawes explains: “As UK economic confidence improves still further and the market continues its upward trend, we have revised our 2014 forecast up from 2.3 million to over 2.4 million registrations. This represents an increase of more than 6% versus last year.” While Lord Myners was fielding questions on his report, the disgraced former chair of the Co-op Bank was arriving at Leeds Crown Court. The reverend Paul Flowers is accused of possessing drugs including cocaine and crystal meth. Our Northern editor Helen Pidd is there, and tweets that Rev Flowers arrived before the court was even open. The Unite union has urged Co-op delegates to back Lord Myners' recommendations. Myners report is the only chance to deliver a future for the Co-op and its members, and guarantee jobs, argued Unite national officer, Adrian Jones, who warned: “Our members embrace the Co-op’s unique ethos and have been working tirelessly to make the group a success, but they are increasingly feeling frustrated that their livelihoods are being overlooked in the internal power struggles over whether to reform the group. A quick recap: Former City minister Lord Myners has warned that the current board of the Co-operative Group is not competent to carry out its duties, in a press conference call to discuss his report into the crisis at the Co-op, published this morning (and online here). Myners said the current board lacks the expertise and business know-how required, and has allowed previous management to "run circles" around them. It needs a new "PLC-plus" set-up, of experienced independent directors working alongside the management, rather than today's set-up where people rise to the top through the Co-op's local area and regional boards. He said the resignation of former CEO Euan Sutherland was a 'catastrophe' for the group. Myners warned that the Co-op's banks are likely to take a "greater interest" in the company, if it does not make the changes he recommends. He expects it will continue with its plan to sell its farms business and pharmacy chain, but warned there is "reluctance" at the board level to accept the need to dispose of some assets. He argued that the future of the Co-op, with its 100,000 employees across the UK, was a serious national issue - contrasting it with the furore over Pfizer's attempts to take over AstraZeneca, which employs 6,700 in the UK. If the Co-op gets it right, and adopts his recommendations at its AGM on May 17, it could still have a bright future, he suggested. Myners believes the independent societies who own around a fifth of the Co-op will back his plan, with one exception. But he has no idea how delegates representing the Co-op's regional bodies, and its 8 million members, will vote. During the call, Myners also pointed out that Co-op Board members also sit on their local area committee and regional boards and many also take on other paid governance roles. This means that, for some, it can be quite lucrative, he agues. This table, from today's report (online here) has the details. The report says that All current Group Board members sit on an Area Committee and Regional Board and many also take on other paid governance roles either on Group Subsidiary Boards and committees and/or on the boards of sister organisations. And lay board directors received between £18,000 (for part of the year) and £44,000 in 2013 - depending how many roles they performed. Lord Myners concluded the press call by saying that he has played the role of a doctor, during his assessment of the Co-operative group. I have examined the patient in a lot of detail, he says, and I have prescribed what the patient needs to do. But it's not up to the eight million members, it's up to the 100 elected democrats [the delegates from the regional boards] from the regions who will vote at the AGM on 17 May. Myners thinks that he will get the support of all but one of the independent societies - who own 22% of the Co-op. But he has no idea how the 15 regional members, who represent the 8 million members, will cast their block votes. And, curiously, the vote takes place on the Saturday morning -- followed by the debate on the report!. Another example of the "topsy turvy" democracy which one associates with the Co-op Group, Myners concludes. And that was the end of the call. The loss of Euan Sutherland as CEO is a catastrophe for the Co-op Group, Lord Myners says. He was forced out by some people who should "lower their heads in shame", he added. Sutherland quit in March, after details of his £6.6m pay package were leaked to The Observer. The Co-op is the least well placed of the 10 major grocery chains to cope with a major price war, Myners says. But he adds that its head of food, Steve Murrells, is "first class". Myners expects the Co-op will press on with the sales of its pharmacy and farms operations, and will come under pressure to sell its funerals business too. On governance issues, Myners says that the Co-op members never voted on the decision to fund the Co-operative party. And he never heard the board discussing the recent price cutting in the supermarket business. Should the Co-op board resign? Myners replies that the current board does not includes anyone with a background in business. That was clear within half an hour of my first board meeting, he says. They have a complete inability to understand the basic issues and ask the right questions. The model where people are elected to regional boards, and then to the top board, simply doesn't work, Myners says, concluding that: This board is not competent to perform the duties expected of it, he concludes. My colleague Jill Treanor asks about Paul Myners suggestion that the Co-op could potentially be wound down into a charitable foundation to fund its social purposes. webTitle: Candy Crush developer shares slide 13% on Wall Street as players lose interest

fields.standfirst: Investors disregarded overall return to revenue growth after King Digital reveals $63m fall in revenues from hit smartphone title
fields.body:
King Digital, the newly floated British games firm behind Candy Crush Saga, has seen its shares plunge 13% after revealing a $63m drop in revenues from the hit smartphone title as players begin to lose interest.

Nervous investors disregarded an overall return to revenue growth at King Digital, which has lost nearly a quarter of its stockmarket value since floating on the New York Stock Exchange in March.

Reporting its maiden results as a public company, King said gross bookings – revenues before the commission paid to platform owners like Apple and Facebook – rose by a better than expected 1% during the first three months of the year. They totalled $641m (£378m) in the first quarter, up $9m from Christmas but still down from a peak of $648m in the third quarter of 2013.

But the contribution to bookings from Candy Crush fell from $493m in the last quarter of 2013 to $430m in the first three months of this year. Monthly unique payers across all games also fell, from 12.2 million in the final quarter of last year to 11.9 million this quarter, as the number of one-off Candy Crush customers diminished. King Digital lets customers play its games for free but encourages spending on booster elements like extra lives.

As internet stocks continued to tumble across Wall Street, with AOL losing a quarter of its value after reporting lower than expected earnings, King Digital's shares were driven as low as $16.09 during morning trading, within a few cents of the record low of $15.84 set on 15 April, and a long way from the $22.50 float price.

The company's market capitalisation has slumped from $7bn, when it went public, to $5.3bn, as investors question its dependence on a single blockbuster game.

Finance director Hope Cochran said the fall in paying players was "entirely expected". It was also linked to the introduction of gold bars, a virtual currency used in firm's Facebook games which it intends to roll out to smartphone titles. Mobile accounts for 75% of King Digital's revenues. Gross average bookings per paying user are $18, up from nearly $16 a year ago.

Asked about the poor share price performance, its chief executive, Riccardo Zacconi said: "The judgment is made by the market at any moment in time. My only focus is in building a company which is solid, which is profitable in the long term."

He forecast full-year bookings of between $2.55bn and $2.65bn, saying the release of new games would accelerate towards the end of the year, with more smartphone adaptations of popular titles from its royalgames.com website.

The firm's bias is moving from sweets to agriculture, as the fall in revenues from confectionery themed Candy Crush is balanced by the growth of its Farm Heroes Saga game, in which players collect apples, strawberries and sunshine to grow their scores. Farm Heroes saw its daily active users increase from 9 million in the Christmas quarter to 20 million in the first three months of 2014 after launching on smartphone platform in January.

"We are building a portfolio of strong games and with this portfolio we believe we will have a much more stable base of users for the long term," said Zacconi.
